claim: Henry III of France died without a successor.

supporting.text: Henry III of France had no surviving children or direct male heirs at the time of his death in 1589.

attacks.text: Henry III of France had no surviving children or direct male heirs at the time of his death in 1589.
Henry III of France had a younger brother, Francis II of France, who survived him and became king.
Henry III's wife, Louise of Lorraine, gave birth to a daughter who could have inherited the throne.
Francis II of France died before Henry III, making him irrelevant as a successor.
The daughter of Henry III was not recognized as a legitimate heir due to Salic Law restrictions.
Francis II's death occurred in 1560, decades before Henry III's reign, so he could not have succeeded him in 1589.
Salic Law explicitly excluded female heirs from inheriting the French throne during this period.

supporting.text: His only son Louis de Valois died in infancy before Henry III's reign ended.

attacks.text: His only son Louis de Valois died in infancy before Henry III's reign ended.
Henry III had multiple surviving male relatives beyond his son Louis de Valois.
French succession laws permitted indirect heirs through paternal uncles during crises.
Louis de Valois was explicitly designated as heir by royal decree prior to his death.
Paternal uncles lacked constitutional priority over direct descendants under Salic Law.
Royal decrees explicitly excluded paternal uncles from succession during this period.
Salic Law prioritized direct lineage over hypothetical indirect claims.

supporting.text: The French crown passed directly to his younger brother Henry IV upon his death due to Salic Law restrictions on female inheritance.

attacks.text: The French crown passed directly to his younger brother Henry IV upon his death due to Salic Law restrictions on female inheritance.
The Salic Law did not strictly apply in 1589 because it was modified by subsequent royal decrees allowing female succession in specific cases.
Henry III had surviving male relatives beyond his brother Henry IV who could have claimed the throne under alternative interpretations of succession rules.
Contemporary legal documents from 1589 explicitly cite the Salic Law as preventing female inheritance and legitimizing Henry IV's claim.
Historical records confirm no viable male relatives existed after Henry III's death besides his brother Henry IV due to prior royal line extinctions.
The cited legal documents in C1 were later proven to be forged or misinterpreted during modern historical analysis.
The claim of 'royal line extinctions' in C2 ignores documented claims by distant male cousins through secondary branches of the Valois family.

supporting.text: Henry IV of France was already alive and positioned as heir apparent when Henry III died.

attacks.text: Henry IV of France was already alive and positioned as heir apparent when Henry III died.
Henry IV of France was not officially recognized as heir apparent during Henry III's reign; his claim faced significant opposition from Catholic factions.
The existence of multiple claimants during the succession crisis undermines the assertion that Henry IV was positioned as heir.
The Estates-General did confirm Henri de Navarre as heir following Charles IX's death.
The succession crisis resolved with Henri de Navarre becoming king after military victories.
The Estates-General's approval was conditional and contested by nobles who favored other candidates.
Military victories did not resolve all opposition; many still disputed his legitimacy due to religious differences.

supporting.text: The Valois dynasty's succession structure ensured proximity of royal bloodlines even without direct descendants.

attacks.text: The Valois dynasty's succession structure ensured proximity of royal bloodlines even without direct descendants.
The Valois succession rules explicitly excluded female heirs and distant relatives, creating a vacuum when Henry III died.
Henry III's death in 1589 led to immediate conflict over succession due to competing claims from non-Valois branches.
The exclusion of female heirs was a deliberate policy to prevent fragmentation of royal authority.
The conflict over succession in 1589 was resolved by constitutional mechanisms rather than structural failure.
Constitutional mechanisms in 1589 prioritized primogeniture over proximity of bloodlines.
The Valois dynasty's reliance on male-line succession created predictable gaps when branches died out.
